awd_titl_txt: Research in Quantum Field Theory: Anomalous Properties of Chiral Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
The properties of matter at extreme densities and temperatures are of great interest in nuclear physics. The corresponding extreme conditions are realized in the primordial plasma of the early Universe, in the fireballs produced by heavy-ion colliders, as well as in the interiors of neutron stars. Such forms of matter are relativistic because their constituent particles move with speeds close to the speed of light. More importantly, the particles carry a quantum characteristic, called chirality, that can give rise to very unusual macroscopic properties of matter. In this project, the PI will study the underlying physics behind a wide range of chiral properties of relativistic matter. The research outcomes will be relevant also for recently discovered Dirac and Weyl materials that have pseudorelativistic charge carriers and hold a great promise for new technologies. The project will be a platform for training undergraduate and graduate students, who will acquire deep knowledge of physics and mathematics, as well as invaluable analytical and problem solving skills that will help them upon entering the highly educated workforce of the future knowledge-based economy. 

In this project, the PI and his collaborators will study a wide range of chiral properties of relativistic and pseudorelativistic forms of matter. A special emphasis will be placed on finding macroscopic signature observables that are induced by the chiral anomaly. Using first-principle quantum-field theoretical methods and techniques, and supplementing them with methods of chiral kinetic theory and hydrodynamics, the PI will investigate the following topics: (i) the properties of collective modes and their anomalous features in various regimes of chiral (pseudo-)relativistic plasmas, (ii) the role of nonuniform flow and inhomogeneities in chiral plasmas and their implications for  the evolution of the early Universe, (iii) the limitations of the chiral kinetic theory and the ways of circumventing them by using quantum field theory, and (iv) the observable consequences of the chiral asymmetry and chiral effects in Dirac and Weyl materials. The outcomes of this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of theoretical implications of quantum anomalies, as well as of their macroscopic observable effects.

por.por_cntn:
The project aim was to expand the theoretical knowledge about the anomalous properties of relativistic plasmas under extreme conditions. Such plasmas appear in many physical systems. They include dense matter inside neutron stars, the hot plasma of the early Universe, the quark-gluon plasma produced by heavy-ion collisions, and the electromagnetic plasmas in the magnetospheres of black holes and magnetars. A quasi-relativistic electron plasma with similar properties also forms in the novel materials called Dirac and Weyl semimetals.

The main outcomes of the project are (i) calculation of the rates of dilepton and photon production in a strongly magnetized plasma, (ii) calculation of the angular dependence and ellipticity of particle production as an indirect measure of the magnetic field in heavy-ion collisions, (iii) proposal of a new mechanism in the magnetar magnetospheres with a potential relevance to the physics of fast radio bursts, (iv) development of a new method for calculating the polarization effects in strongly magnetized plasmas, (v) the explanation of a strong suppression of the electron fluid convection in topological semimetals, (vi) the prediction of a novel type of plasma instability in topological semimetals. These results provide new knowledge about (quasi-)relativistic plasmas. 

Generally, the project results contributed to a better understanding of how magnetic fields affect the fundamental properties of relativistic plasmas. The theoretical insight into the details of particle production from a magnetized plasma can guide future explorations in heavy-ion collisions, observational features of magnetars, and the plasma dynamics in the early Universe. Among other outcomes, the project shed light on the plasma properties related to the chiral anomaly, which is one of the most enigmatic phenomena in quantum theory. The chiral anomalous properties promise the development of future quantum materials with desired technological properties.

The project served as a platform for educating and training undergraduate and graduate students. Such participation in original research is invaluable for students to develop strong analytical and problem solving skills. The PI mentored doctoral-level graduate students. One of them finished the program and received the Ph.D. degree in May 2019.
